query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 In quella parte del giovanetto anno 2 che ’l sole i crin sotto l’Aquario tempra 3 e già le notti al mezzo dì sen vanno,
4 quando la brina in su la terra assempra 5 l’imagine di sua sorella bianca, 6 ma poco dura a la sua penna tempra,
7 lo villanello a cui la roba manca, 8 si leva, e guarda, e vede la campagna 9 biancheggiar tutta; ond’ ei si batte l’anca,
10 ritorna in casa, e qua e là si lagna, 11 come ’l tapin che non sa che si faccia; 12 poi riede, e la speranza ringavagna,
13 veggendo ’l mondo aver cangiata faccia 14 in poco d’ora, e prende suo vincastro 15 e fuor le pecorelle a pascer caccia.
query.result:
1 In that part of the youthful year 2 when the sun tempers its hair under Aquarius 3 and already the nights are waning towards midday,
4 when the frost on the ground 5 resembles the image of its white sister, 6 but its pen does not hold its temper for long,
7 the peasant, who lacks provisions, 8 gets up, looks out, and sees the countryside 9 all turning white; whereupon he beats his thigh,
10 goes back inside, and complains here and there, 11 like the wretch who doesn't know what to do; 12 then he goes out again, and regains hope,
13 seeing that the world has changed its face 14 in a short time, and he takes his crook 15 and drives his sheep out to pasture.

16 Thus did the master make me lose heart 17 when I saw his brow so troubled, 18 and so quickly did the plaster come to the sore;
19 for, as we came to the ruined bridge, 20 the leader turned to me with that gentle expression 21 that I had first seen at the foot of the mountain.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
22 Le braccia aperse, dopo alcun consiglio 23 eletto seco riguardando prima 24 ben la ruina, e diedemi di piglio.
query.result: 22 He opened his arms, after some counsel 23 chosen with himself, first looking well 24 at the ruin, and seized me.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
25 E come quei ch’adopera ed estima, 26 che sempre par che ’nnanzi si proveggia, 27 così, levando me sù ver’ la cima
28 d’un ronchione, avvisava un’altra scheggia 29 dicendo: «Sovra quella poi t’aggrappa; 30 ma tenta pria s’è tal ch’ella ti reggia».
query.result:
25 And like one who works and thinks, 26 who always seems to be providing for what is to come, 27 so, lifting me up towards the top
28 of a large rock, he spied another splinter, 29 saying: "Then climb onto that one; 30 but first try if it is strong enough to hold you."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
31 Non era via da vestito di cappa, 32 ché noi a pena, ei lieve e io sospinto, 33 potavam sù montar di chiappa in chiappa.
query.result: 31 It was not a path for someone wearing a cape, 32 for we, he lightly and I pushed from behind, 33 could barely climb from slab to slab.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
34 E se non fosse che da quel precinto 35 più che da l’altro era la costa corta, 36 non so di lui, ma io sarei ben vinto.
query.result: 34 And if it were not that from that side 35 the slope was shorter than from the other, 36 I don't know about him, but I would have been well and truly beaten.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
37 Ma perché Malebolge inver’ la porta 38 del bassissimo pozzo tutta pende, 39 lo sito di ciascuna valle porta
40 che l’una costa surge e l’altra scende; 41 noi pur venimmo al fine in su la punta 42 onde l’ultima pietra si scoscende.
query.result:
37 But because Malebolge, towards the gate 38 of the lowest pit, slopes all the way down, 39 the layout of each valley means
40 that one side rises and the other descends; 41 we nevertheless finally came to the point 42 where the last stone juts out.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
43 La lena m’era del polmon sì munta 44 quand’ io fui sù, ch’i’ non potea più oltre, 45 anzi m’assisi ne la prima giunta.
query.result: 43 My lungs were so exhausted 44 when I reached the top that I could go no further, 45 indeed I sat down as soon as I arrived.

46 "Now it is necessary for you to bestir yourself in this way," 47 said the master; "for, by sitting on feathers, 48 one does not come to fame, nor under a quilt;
49 without which, whoever wastes his life, 50 leaves such a trace of himself on earth, 51 as smoke in the air and foam on the water.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
52 E però leva sù; vinci l’ambascia 53 con l’animo che vince ogne battaglia, 54 se col suo grave corpo non s’accascia.
query.result: 52 And therefore get up; overcome the shortness of breath 53 with the spirit that wins every battle, 54 if it does not collapse under its own heavy body.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
55 Più lunga scala convien che si saglia; 56 non basta da costoro esser partito. 57 Se tu mi ’ntendi, or fa sì che ti vaglia».

Please translate each line literally into English.
58 Leva’mi allor, mostrandomi fornito 59 meglio di lena ch’i’ non mi sentia, 60 e dissi: «Va, ch’i’ son forte e ardito».
query.result: 58 He lifted me up then, showing me to be 59 better supplied with breath than I felt, 60 and I said: "Go on, for I am strong and bold."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
61 Su per lo scoglio prendemmo la via, 62 ch’era ronchioso, stretto e malagevole, 63 ed erto più assai che quel di pria.
query.result: 61 We took the path over the crag, 62 which was rough, narrow and difficult, 63 and much steeper than the previous one.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
64 Parlando andava per non parer fievole; 65 onde una voce uscì de l’altro fosso, 66 a parole formar disconvenevole.

Please translate each line literally into English.
67 Non so che disse, ancor che sovra ’l dosso 68 fossi de l’arco già che varca quivi; 69 ma chi parlava ad ire parea mosso.

Please translate each line literally into English.
70 Io era vòlto in giù, ma li occhi vivi 71 non poteano ire al fondo per lo scuro; 72 per ch’io: «Maestro, fa che tu arrivi
73 da l’altro cinghio e dismontiam lo muro; 74 ché, com’ i’ odo quinci e non intendo, 75 così giù veggio e neente affiguro».

Please translate each line literally into English.
76 «Altra risposta», disse, «non ti rendo 77 se non lo far; ché la dimanda onesta 78 si de’ seguir con l’opera tacendo».
query.result: 76 "I will give you no other answer," he said, 77 "than to do it; for an honest request 78 should be followed up with action, without words."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
79 Noi discendemmo il ponte da la testa 80 dove s’aggiugne con l’ottava ripa, 81 e poi mi fu la bolgia manifesta:
82 e vidivi entro terribile stipa 83 di serpenti, e di sì diversa mena 84 che la memoria il sangue ancor mi scipa.
query.result:
79 We descended the bridge from the head 80 where it joins the eighth bank, 81 and then the ditch was revealed to me:
82 and I saw within it a terrifying throng 83 of serpents, and of such diverse kinds 84 that the memory still chills my blood.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
85 Più non si vanti Libia con sua rena; 86 ché se chelidri, iaculi e faree 87 produce, e cencri con anfisibena,
88 né tante pestilenzie né sì ree 89 mostrò già mai con tutta l’Etïopia 90 né con ciò che di sopra al Mar Rosso èe.
query.result:
85 Let Libya no longer boast of its sands; 86 for even if it produces vipers, darting snakes and adders, 87 and horned vipers with amphisbaenas,
88 it never displayed so many or such foul pests 89 with all of Ethiopia 90 or with all that lies above the Red Sea.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
91 Tra questa cruda e tristissima copia 92 corrëan genti nude e spaventate, 93 sanza sperar pertugio o elitropia:
94 con serpi le man dietro avean legate; 95 quelle ficcavan per le ren la coda 96 e ’l capo, ed eran dinanzi aggroppate.
query.result:
91 Among this cruel and most fearsome throng 92 ran naked and terrified people, 93 with no hope of a loophole or heliotrope:
94 their hands were bound behind them with snakes; 95 the snakes thrust their tails and heads 96 through their loins, and were knotted in front.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
97 Ed ecco a un ch’era da nostra proda, 98 s’avventò un serpente che ’l trafisse 99 là dove ’l collo a le spalle s’annoda.
query.result: 97 And behold, a serpent darted at one who was on our side, 98 and pierced him where the neck joins the shoulders.

100 Never was an O or an I written so quickly, 101 as he caught fire and burned, and had to fall 102 and become ash;
103 and after he was so destroyed on the ground, 104 the dust gathered itself together 105 and suddenly returned to the same form.

106 Thus it is acknowledged by the great sages 107 that the phoenix dies and then is reborn, 108 when it approaches its five-hundredth year;
109 it eats neither grass nor grain in its life, 110 but only feeds on tears of frankincense and amomum, 111 and nard and myrrh are its final wrappings.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
112 E qual è quel che cade, e non sa como, 113 per forza di demon ch’a terra il tira, 114 o d’altra oppilazion che lega l’omo,
115 quando si leva, che ’ntorno si mira 116 tutto smarrito de la grande angoscia 117 ch’elli ha sofferta, e guardando sospira:
118 tal era ’l peccator levato poscia.
query.result:
112 And just as someone who falls, and does not know how, 113 through the power of a demon that drags him to the ground, 114 or some other obstruction that binds a man,
115 when he gets up, looks around himself, 116 completely bewildered by the great anguish 117 that he has suffered, and sighs as he looks:
118 such was the sinner after he had risen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
119 Oh potenza di Dio, quant’ è severa, 120 che cotai colpi per vendetta croscia!
121 Lo duca il domandò poi chi ello era; 122 per ch’ei rispuose: «Io piovvi di Toscana, 123 poco tempo è, in questa gola fiera.
query.result:
119 Oh, the power of God, how severe it is, 120 that it rains down such blows in vengeance!
121 The leader then asked him who he was; 122 to which he replied: "I fell from Tuscany, 123 a short time ago, into this fierce pit.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
124 Vita bestial mi piacque e non umana, 125 sì come a mul ch’i’ fui; son Vanni Fucci 126 bestia, e Pistoia mi fu degna tana».
query.result: 124 I took pleasure in a bestial life, not a human one, 125 just like the mule that I was; I am Vanni Fucci, 126 a beast, and Pistoia was a worthy den for me."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
127 E ïo al duca: «Dilli che non mucci, 128 e domanda che colpa qua giù ’l pinse; 129 ch’io ’l vidi uomo di sangue e di crucci».

query.result:
130 And the sinner, who understood, did not dissemble, 131 but turned his spirit and face towards me, 132 and painted himself with the colors of sad shame;
133 then he said: "It grieves me more that you have caught me 134 in the misery in which you see me, 135 than when I was taken from the other life.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
136 Io non posso negar quel che tu chiedi; 137 in giù son messo tanto perch’ io fui 138 ladro a la sagrestia d’i belli arredi,
139 e falsamente già fu apposto altrui.
query.result:
136 I cannot deny what you ask; 137 I am placed down here so low because I was 138 a thief who stole the beautiful furnishings from the sacristy,
139 and the blame was falsely put on someone else.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
140 Ma perché di tal vista tu non godi, 141 se mai sarai di fuor da’ luoghi bui,
142 apri li orecchi al mio annunzio, e odi.
query.result:
140 But so that you may not enjoy such a sight, 141 if ever you should be outside these dark places,
142 open your ears to my announcement, and listen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
151 E detto l’ho perché doler ti debbia!».
query.result: 151 And I have said it so that you may grieve!"
